facts.text: Civil Appeal No.760 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.C.C Appeal No. 5 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICATION Civil Appeal No.760 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in C.C.C Appeal No. 5 of 1960. V. Pillai and M. M. Kshatriya, for the appellants.

facts.text: The suit is for recovery of possession of the house known as Sama Khana and five tiled rooms inside the company pound of a dargah at Katalamandi, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit for the recovery of possession of the house known as Sama Khana and five tiled rooms inside the companypound of a dargah at Katalamandi, Hyderabad. The property belongs to Dargah Hazarat Habbeeb Ali Shah Saheb.

facts.text: The property belongs to Dargah Hazarat Habbeeb Ali Shah Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: The property belongs to Dargah Hazarat Habbeeb Ali Shah Saheb. The dargah while in possession of the property was dispossessed by the defendants long ago.

facts.text: The dargah was dispossessed of the property by the defendants on or about September 20, 1937, when the defendants filed objections in the course of certain proceedings for enrolment of the property as endowed property under the Hyderabad Endowment Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: The dargah while in possession of the property was dispossessed by the defendants long ago. Counsel for the plaintiffs conceded before us that the dargah was dispossessed of the property on or about September 20, 1937, when the defendants filed objections in the companyrse of certain proceedings for enrolment of the property as endowed property under the Hyderabad Endowment Regulations.

facts.text: Under the Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F, there was no limitation for a suit for recovery of a wakf property by virtue of section 29c.

anchor.surface_text: While the Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F was in force in Hyderabad, there was numberlimitation for a suit for recovery of a wakf property. Section 29 c  of the Act applied to suits relating to wakf. By virtue of s. 29 c , a suit for recovery of a wakf property was outside the Act.

facts.text: The Part B States Laws Act, 1951 came into force on April 1, 1951 and extended the Indian Limitation Act 1908 to Hyderabad, repealing the corresponding law in force in Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1951, the Part B States  Laws  Act.- 1951, came into force and extended the Indian Limitation Act 1908 to Hyderabad, and the companyresponding law in force in Hyderabad stood repealed.

facts.text: The mutawalli of the dargah and the Board of Muslim Endowments, Hyderabad, instituted the suit on February 3, 1956 for recovery of the property from the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: On February 3, 1956, the mutawalli of the dargah and the Board of Muslim Endowments, Hyderabad, instituted the present suit for recovery of the property from the defendants.

facts.text: The trial court dismissed the suit on the ground that it was barred by limitation under Article 142 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit on the ground that it was so barred. On appeal, the High Court of Andhra Pradesh held that the suit was governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act and was number barred by limitation.

facts.text: The High Court of Andhra Pradesh decreed the suit holding it was governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act and not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Andhra Pradesh held that the suit was governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act and was number barred by limitation. On this finding the High Court decreed the suit.

facts.text: Some of the defendants appealed to the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the defendants number appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: The Part B States Laws Act 1951 was passed on February 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Part B States  Laws  Act 1951 was passed on February 22, 1951. The Act came into force on April 1, 1951 by virtue of a numberification of the Central Government dated March 7, 1951 and published in the gazette on March 10, 1915.

facts.text: Section 30 of the Part B States Laws Act provides for suits where the period prescribed by Indian Limitation Act is shorter than previous law, allowing institution within two years after coming into force or the previous period, whichever expires first.

anchor.surface_text: It extended to the Part B States the Indian Limitation Act 1908 as amended with the addition of s. 30 which is in these terms Provision for States for which the period prescribed is shorter than that prescribed by any law previously in force in. a Part B State. Notwithstanding anything herein companytained, any suit for which the period of limitation prescribed by this Act is shorter than the period of limitation prescribed by any law companyresponding to this Act in force in a Part B State which is repealed by the Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951, may be instituted within the period of two years next after the companying into force of this Act in that Part B States or within the period prescribed for such suit by such companyresponding law, whichever period expires first.

facts.text: Under Hyderabad law, there was no limitation period for recovery of wakf property, while Article 142 of Indian Limitation Act 1908 prescribes a shorter period.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Hyderabad Limitation Act did number apply to a suit for recovery of possession of a wakf property. The result was that under the companyresponding law in force in Hyderabad, there was numberlimitation for such a suit. In other words, the period of limitation prescribed for the suit by the companyresponding law in Hyderabad was an unlimited period.

facts.text: Section 30 enabled plaintiffs to institute the suit within two years after April 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Article 142 of the Indian Limitation Act 1908 applies to a suit for recovery of possession of the wakf property. As it prescribes a shorter period of limitation for the institution of the suit, s. 30 enabled the plaintiffs to institute the suit within a period of two years after April 1, 1951.

facts.text: The suit was instituted more than two years after April 1, 1951, so plaintiffs cannot avail benefit of Section 30.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs did number institute the suit within two years after April 1, 1951. They cannot therefore avail themselves of the benefit of s. 30.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the suit is governed by the Indian Limitation Act 1908 in force at the date of institution.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, apply the numbermal rule that the law of limitation applicable to the suit is the law in force at the date of the institution of the suit. The suit is, therefore, governed by the Indian Limitation Act 1908.

facts.text: Counsel for plaintiffs submitted that the suit was by or on behalf of the State Government governed by Article 149.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel submitted that the present suit was a suit by or on behalf of the State Government and was therefore governed by art. 149 of the Indian Limitation Act 1908.

facts.text: The Board of Muslim Endowments is not an agent of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the Board of Wakfs is number an agent of the State Government and a suit instituted by it for the recovery of a wakf property is number a suit by or on behalf of the State Government.

facts.text: The mutawalli is not the agent of the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Since the passing of the Religious Endowments Act 1863, the mutawalli cannot be regarded as a procurator of the Government.

facts.text: The date of dispossession of the wakf is September 20, 1937, the starting point of limitation under Article 142.

anchor.surface_text: The date of dispossession of the wakf is the starting point of limitation under this article. It was suggested that as limitation did number run under the Hyderabad Limitation Act, the date when the Indian Limitation Act 1908 came into force in Hyderabad should be regarded as the starting point of limitation.

facts.text: On August 13, 1941, defendants instituted a suit for declaration of title and obtained injunction restraining enrolment.

anchor.surface_text: On August 13, 1941 the defendants instituted a suit for a declaration of there title to the property and obtained an injunction restraining the enrolment of the property in the Book of Endowment.

facts.text: On March 10, 1942, the defendants' suit was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 10, 1942, the suit was dismissed.

facts.text: On May 18, 1942, the property was enrolled in the Book of Endowment.

anchor.surface_text: On May 18, 1942, the property was enrolled in the Book of Endowment.

facts.text: On May 21, 1942, summary proceedings for recovery under s.14 Hyderabad Endowment Regulation were started by the dargah before Addl. Chief Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On May 21, 1942, summary proceedings for the recovery of the property by the dargah were started under s. 14 of the Hyderabad Endowment Regulation before the Addl. Chief Judge, City Civil. Court, Hyderabad at the instance of the Director, Ecclesiastical Department of the Government of Hyderabad.

facts.text: On October 15, 1945, the High Court allowed the defendants' appeal and remanded the suit.

anchor.surface_text: On October 15, 1945 the High Court allowed the appeal and remanded the suit to the trial companyrt for disposal according to law,

facts.text: On August 28, 1948, the trial court dismissed the defendants' suit.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28, 1948, the trial companyrt dismissed the suit.

facts.text: On September 21, 1955, an appeal by defendants from the decree was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1955, an appeal filed by the defendants from this decree was dismissed

facts.text: The Supreme Court held the suit barred by limitation as instituted more than 12 years after dispossession.

anchor.surface_text: As the suit was instituted more than 12 years after the date of dispossession,. it is barred by limitation and must be dismissed.

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court decree, and restored the trial court decree dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed. The decree of the High Court is set aside and the decree of the trial companyrt is restored. The suit is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 12, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court

While the Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F was in force in Hyderabad, there was no limitation for a suit for recovery of a wakf property. Section 29 c  of the Act applied to suits relating to wakf.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Part B States  Laws  Act 1951 was passed on February 22, 1951. The Act came into force on April 1, 1951 by virtue of a notification of the Central Government dated March 7, 1951 and published in the gazette on March 10, 1951. It extended to the Part B States the Indian Limitation Act 1908 as amended with the addition of s. 30 which is in these terms Provision for States for which the period prescribed is shorter than that prescribed by any law previously in force in. a Part B State. Notwithstanding anything herein contained, any suit for which the period of limitation prescribed by this Act is shorter than the period of limitation prescribed by any law corresponding to this Act in force in a Part B State which is repealed by the Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951, may be instituted within the period of two years next after the coming into force of this Act in that Part B States or within the period prescribed for such suit by such corresponding law, whichever period expires first.

concepts.interpretation: Section 30 should be construed liberally considering that it is intended to alleviate hardship consequent on the introduction of a shorter period of limitation. Ex-facie, S. 30 applies to a suit for which the period of limitation prescribed by the Indian Limitation Act 1908 is shorter than the period of limitation prescribed by the corresponding law in force in the Part B State.

issues.text: Whether the suit is governed by the Indian Limitation Act, 1908 and barred under Article 142 thereof or by the Hyderabad Limitation Act under which there was no limitation for recovery of wakf property?

anchor.surface_text: While the Hyderabad Limitation Act II of 1322 F was in force in Hyderabad, there was no limitation for a suit for recovery of a wakf property. Section 29 c  of the Act applied to suits relating to wakf. By virtue of s. 29 c , a suit for recovery of a wakf property was outside the Act. On April 1, 1951, the Part B States  Laws  Act.- 1951, came into force and extended the Indian Limitation Act 1908 to Hyderabad, and the corresponding law in force in Hyderabad stood repealed.

issues.text: Whether Section 30 of the Part B States Laws Act, 1951 applies to the suit providing a two-year period for institution after April 1, 1951?

anchor.surface_text: Now, the Part B States  Laws  Act 1951 was passed on February 22, 1951. The Act came into force on April 1, 1951 by virtue of a notification of the Central Government dated March 7, 1951 and published in the gazette on March 10, 1951. It extended to the Part B States the Indian Limitation Act 1908 as amended with the addition of s. 30 which is in these terms Provision for States for which the period prescribed is shorter than that prescribed by any law previously in force in. a Part B State. Notwithstanding anything herein contained, any suit for which the period of limitation prescribed by this Act is shorter than the period of limitation prescribed by any law corresponding to this Act in force in a Part B State which is repealed by the Part B States  Laws  Act, 1951, may be instituted within the period of two years next after the coming into force of this Act in that Part B States or within the period prescribed for such suit by such corresponding law, whichever period expires first.

issues.text: Whether the present suit was a suit by or on behalf of the State Government and therefore governed by Article 149 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel submitted that the present suit was a suit by or on behalf of the State Government and was therefore governed by art. 149 of the Indian Limitation Act 1908. He submitted that the Board of Muslim Endowments, Hyderabad, which according to him was the Board of Wakfs constituted under the Muslim Wakfs Act 1954, was an agent of the Central Government.

issues.text: Whether the Board of Wakfs is an agent of the State Government?

anchor.surface_text: By s. 9 2  of the Muslim Wakfs Act, 1954, the Board of Wakfs is a body corporate and by s. 15 of this Act, the Board is vested with the right of general superintendence of wakfs and is empowered to take measures for the recovery of the lost properties of any wakf and to initiate and defend suits and proceedings relating to wakfs. Counsel submitted that a corporation may be an agent of the State Government...

issues.text: Whether the mutawalli is an agent of the State Government such that limitation starts from date of appointment?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel next submitted that the mutawalli is the agent of the State Government and that in any event the limitation for a suit by the mutawalli starts on the date of his appointment. In support of this contention counsel relied upon the decision in Jewun Doss Sahoo v. Shah Kubeer-ood Deen, 1  where the Privy Council held that under the law then in force it was the duty of the Government to protect endowments and the mutawalli in that case was the procurator of the Government and his right to sue arose on his being appointed mutawalli.

issues.text: Whether the plaintiffs are entitled to exclusion of time under Sections 14 and 15 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908?

anchor.surface_text: We may now briefly notice two contentions based on ss.14 and 15 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908 On August 13, 1941 the defendants instituted a suit for a declaration of there title to the property and obtained an injunction restraining the enrolment of the property in the Book of Endowment. On March 10, 1942, the suit was dismissed.

issues.text: What is the starting point of limitation under Article 142 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908?

anchor.surface_text: The suit is governed by art. 142. The date of dispossession of the wakf is the starting point of limitation under this article. It was suggested that as limitation did not run under the Hyderabad Limitation Act, the date when the Indian Limitation Act 1908 came into force in Hyderabad should be regarded as the starting point of limitation. This suggestion has no force.

issues.answer: date of dispossession on or about September 20, 1937

arguments.claim: The suit is governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act and is not barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court of Andhra Pradesh held that the suit was governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act and was not barred by limitation. On this finding the High Court decreed the suit. Some of the defendants appeal to this Court by special leave. The High Court held that the application of the Indian Limitation Act 1908 to the suit would bar and confiscate the existing cause of action for the recovery of the suit property, as the Part B States Laws Act while extending the Indian Limitation Act to Hyderabad did not allow a reasonable time to the plaintiffs for enforcing the existing cause of action and consequently the Indian Limitation Act could not affect the suit and the suit was governed by the Hyderabad Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: Suit barred by limitation under Art 142 as more than 12 years from dispossession

anchor.surface_text: As the suit was instituted more than 12 years after the date of dispossession, it is barred by limitation and must be dismissed.

holdings.text: The suit is governed by the Indian Limitation Act 1908 as the law in force at the date of institution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation law is procedural; applies prospectively as in force on suit date; s.30 provides grace period preventing confiscation.

holdings.text: Section 30 of Part B States Laws Act applies but plaintiffs cannot avail benefit as suit not filed within 2 years after April 1, 1951.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Indian Act prescribes shorter (12 yr) than unlimited Hyderabad period; s.30 allows 2 yrs grace or prior period first; suit filed Feb 1956 >2 yrs.

holdings.text: Suit not by or on behalf of State Government; not governed by Art 149.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board is statutory corporation with independent powers, not agent; State not liable for its acts.

holdings.text: Board of Wakfs is not an agent of the State Government.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Body corporate under s.9(2) Muslim Wakfs Act; superintendence powers under s.15; State no control over property/funds except supersession; no agency indication.

holdings.text: Mutawalli not agent of State; limitation not starts on appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Since the passing of the Religious Endowments Act 1863, the mutawalli cannot be regarded as a procurator of the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Religious Endowments Act 1863 divested Govt of superintendence; mutawalli manages independently; right to sue arises on wakf dispossession.

holdings.text: Starting point of limitation under Art 142 is date of dispossession (Sept 20, 1937), not Indian Act commencement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hyderabad Act suspended limitation running but did not alter dispossession date; Art 142 starts from dispossession.

holdings.text: No exclusion of time under s.15 Indian Limitation Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Injunction only restrained enrolment/eviction in prior proceedings, not institution of this suit.

holdings.text: No exclusion of time under s.14 Indian Limitation Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not raised below; mixed fact/law; not in SLP petition.

holdings.text: Suit barred by limitation under Art 142; must be dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Filed 1956 >12 yrs from 1937 dispossession; no extensions apply.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court decree set aside; trial court decree restored.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on applicable law and limitation; trial court correct.

precedents.citation: Tamlin v. Hannaford 1 ... 1 1949 2 All E. R. 327

anchor.surface_text: p. 10- Tamlin v. Hannaford 1 , and the observations of Shah, J. in State Trading Corporation of India Limited v. The Commercial Tax Officer 2 . He submitted that the State Government has delegated its functions of superintendence over wakfs to the Board of Wakfs and the Board should therefore be regarded as an agent of the State Government. We are unable to accept this contention.

precedents.cited_proposition: a corporation may be an agent of the State Government

precedents.citation: State Trading Corporation of India Limited v. The Commercial Tax Officer 2 ... A.I.R. 1963 S.C. 811, 849, 850, paras. 115-117

anchor.surface_text: and the observations of Shah, J. in State Trading Corporation of India Limited v. The Commercial Tax Officer 2 . He submitted that the State Government has delegated its functions of superintendence over wakfs to the Board of Wakfs and the Board should therefore be regarded as an agent of the State Government. We are unable to accept this contention. By the Religious Endowments Act 1863, the Government divested itself of the management and superintendence of religious endowments which was vested in

precedents.case_name: State Trading Corporation of India Limited v Commercial Tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: a corporation may be an agent of the State Government

precedents.citation: Jewun Doss Sahoo v. Shah Kubeer-ood Deen, 1 ... 1 2 Moo.1.A. 390 at p.222

anchor.surface_text: Counsel next submitted that the mutawalli is the agent of the State Government and that in any event the limitation for a suit by the mutawalli starts on the date of his appointment. In support of this contention counsel relied upon the decision in Jewun Doss Sahoo v. Shah Kubeer-ood Deen, 1 where the Privy Council held that under the law then in force it was the duty of the Government to protect endowments and the mutawalli in that case was the procurator of the Government and his right to sue arose on his being appointed mutawalli.

precedents.case_name: Jewun Doss Sahoo v Shah Kubeer-ood Deen
precedents.cited_proposition: mutawalli is procurator of the Government and limitation starts on his appointment
precedents.cited_holding: under the law then in force it was the duty of the Government to protect endowments and the mutawalli ... was the procurator of the Government and his right to sue arose on his being appointed mutawalli

precedents.citation: Shaikh Laul Mahomed v. Lalla Brij Kishore 2 ... 2 17 Weekly Reporter Sutherland 430

anchor.surface_text: Since the passing of the Religious Endowments Act 1863, the mutawalli cannot be regarded as a procurator of the Government. He is not appointed by the Government, nor does he manage the endowment on its behalf and a suit by him for the recovery of the wakf property cannot be regarded as a suit on its behalf, see Shaikh Laul Mahomed v. Lalla Brij Kishore 2 and Behari Lal Ors. v. Muhammad Muttaki 3 .

precedents.case_name: Shaikh Laul Mahomed v Lalla Brij Kishore
precedents.cited_proposition: suit by mutawalli for recovery of wakf property cannot be regarded as a suit on behalf of the Government

precedents.citation: Behari Lal Ors. v. Muhammad Muttaki 3 ... 3 . I.L.R 20 All 482, 488

anchor.surface_text: He is not appointed by the Government, nor does he manage the endowment on its behalf and a suit by him for the recovery of the wakf property cannot be regarded as a suit on its behalf, see Shaikh Laul Mahomed v. Lalla Brij Kishore 2 and Behari Lal Ors. v. Muhammad Muttaki 3 . If the wakf while in possession of its property is dispossessed, it has an immediate right to sue for recovery of the property and the limitation for the suit begins to run.

precedents.cited_proposition: suit by mutawalli for recovery of wakf property cannot be regarded as a suit on behalf of the Government

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed. The decree of the High Court is set aside and the decree of the trial court is restored. The suit is dismissed.
